Many classical games, e.g., <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style>, have many types of <style="CurrentLink">Tournaments</style> arranged around them. Sports have been described as games that have organizations arranging tournaments in them and upholding their "official" rules (typically expanded by "tournament rules")<ref name="Sports@Wikipedia"/>

More recent examples of games which have <style="CurrentLink">Tournaments</style> include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20The%20Gathering">Magic: The Gathering</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bloodbowl">Bloodbowl</link></style> (which supports single players to have <style="CurrentLink">Tournaments</style> through AI players in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bloodbowl%20(computer%20game)">computer</link></style> version).
